Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Self-Sustainable Networking of Survivability-Heterogeneous Sensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to study network issues critical for building self-sustainable outdoors sensor networks. The proposed approach is to introduce environmental survivability-heterogeneity to sensor networks, and to exploit it to holistically and efficiently deal with hazardous environmental conditions that are hard to predict. The approach is motivated by the genetic phenomenon, by which an offspring from a large gene pool can improve its survival in light of environmental threats. The main research thrusts include: designing environmental survivability-aware duty-cycle scheduling, routing, MAC and tasking algorithms to sustainable network, designing schemes to improve network fault tolerance by leveraging environmentally robust nodes, and establishing models to characterize environmental conditions and nodes of different modalities and to provide guidelines for network planning. The proposed methodology will be validated through a combination of simulation, analysis, and prototype implementation.

The project will result in an extensive understanding of the conjoining of sensor networks and the physical world, in a new approach of incorporating the heterogeneity in environmental survivability to construct robust sensor networks, in theoretical and practical advances in network planning, duty-cycle scheduling, and fault-tolerance in sensor networks, and in a new set of environmental survivability-aware MAC, routing, and tasking algorithms.

The project is expected to promote the adoption and application of sensor networks through enhancing their survivability in the outdoors environment and, thus, providing better solutions for disaster rescue missions, military surveillance, and intelligent transportation systems. The project will offer an excellent opportunity to broaden the participation of under-represented groups, to boost the effectiveness of networking education, and to engage high-school, undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conditions of natural environment, such as remote forests, or human-made infrastructures, such as bridges, need continuous monitoring to ensure the timely detection of their hazardous changes. Networks of small inexpensive sensors can be deployed to serve this goal. However, keeping the outdoor sensor networks sustainable is challenging due to unavoidable environmental detriments, such as rain. Equipping all the sensors with additional protection can make them robust to environmental damages, but increases the network construction cost. Equipping a portion of sensors with additional protection is a better way to achieve a balance between cost and performance. This project explored the organization and management of such kind of heterogeneous sensor networks.

From the intellectual merit perspective, the completion of the project has the following outcomes: (1) The project provides a deeper understanding of the conjoining and interaction of sensor networks and the physical world for increased survivability and fault tolerance of sensor networks. (2) A novel adaptive scheduling algorithm was designed and evaluated to coordinate the activities of regular sensors and robust sensors to monitor all the critical points of the target area while minimizing and balancing energy consumption.  (3) A new weather adaptive receiver-initiated MAC protocol was designed to work under different weather conditions. The proposed MAC protocol can reduce idle listening time to save energy consumption while provide a relative delay bound in data delivery. (4) A network-coding based data backup mechanism was designed in such heterogeneous sensor networks. (5) A barrier construction algorithm was developed for heterogeneous networks composed of mobile and robust sensors and regular sensors to provide barrier coverage for intruder detection applications.  The algorithms adopted weather forecast information to ensure the barrier coverage in different weather conditions and maximize the network lifetime.

From the broader impact perspective, the completion of the project has the following outcomes: (i) promoting wider adoption and application of wireless networks for national needs; (ii) enhancing a sensor network’s survivability outdoors and thus providing better solutions in disaster rescue, military surveillance and intelligent transportation; and (iii) delivery of scientific papers, technical reports, and open source software.
